citation.article-title: Thermaerobacter marianensis gen. nov., sp. nov., an aerobic extremely thermophilic marine bacterium from the 11,000 m deep Mariana Trench.

p.s: Description of Thermaerobacter marianensis sp. nov.
Thermaerobacter marianensis (ma.ri.a.nen'sis. M.L. masc. adj. marianensis pertaining to the Mariana Trench)
Straight to slightly curved rods, 0.3-0.6 x 2-7 μm, with rounded ends.
Cells stain slightly Gram-positive in the exponential growth phase but Gram-negative in the stationary growth phase.
Exhibits no motility and no flagellum.
Temperature range for growth is 50-80°C, with the optimum being 75°C.
pH range for growth is from 5.4 to 9.5, with optimum growth occurring at 7.0-7.5.
Growth requires sea salts and occurs in the sea salts concentration range of 0.5-5.0% (w/v) with optimum growth occurring at 2.0%.

Grows on yeast extract, peptone, starch, xylan, chitin, casein, Casamino acids, maltotriose, cellobiose, maltose, lactose, trehalose, saccharose, glucose, galactose, xylose, mannitol, inositol, propionate, 2-aminobutyric acid, malate, pyruvate, tartrate, succinate, lactate, acetate, glycerol, valine, isoleucine, cysteine, proline, serine, threonine, asparagine, glutamine, aspartate, glutamate, lysine, arginine or histidine and weakly on cellulose, glycine, alanine, leucine, methionine or phenylalanine.
G + C content of genomic DNA is about 72.5 mol% (HPLC).

Major cellular fatty acids are 52.3 % iso-C17:0, 27.6% C14:1, 9.3% anteiso-C17:0, 4.3% iso-C15:0, 3.5% anteiso-C15:0, 2.1% C16:0 and 0.9% C16:0. 16s rDNA sequence exhibits 85-87% similarity to those of Moorella thermoautotrophicum, Moorella thermoaceticum and Moorella glycerini and 80-85% similarity to rDNA sequences from the members of Thermoanaerobacter and Desulfotomaculum.
Isolate was obtained from a mud sample from the bottom of the Challenger Deep in the Mariana Trench at a depth of 10897 m.
The type strain is Thermaerobacter marianensis 7p75aT, =JCM 10246T, Japan Collection of Microorganisms, The Institute of Physical and Chemical Research (RIKEN), Wako-shi, Saitama, Japan.
